segments.text: In Julio's café, adorned with his beard and worn beret, he tried to focus on the scenery.
He hoped he indeed looked older than his age, not too handsome, a bit hunched, so that no one seeking company would sit beside him.
There is something very warm and unpretentious about the people living on this island.
However, he could not afford connections.
He consistently sat by the large window facing the street, pretending to gaze out, and nothing escaped his attention.
Julio had already tried several times to fix him up with a local woman.

Usually they were full-figured, with prominent buttocks and deep mocha-colored skin, all cheerful and full of life, and most had several children, usually each from a different man who had crossed their path at some point in their lives.
In this place, it's common for grandmothers to raise the grandchildren while the mothers go out to work and support the family.
In the best cases, they also received support from the fathers of their children.
Dan led Julio know he wasn't interested in a match, explaining that he was mourning his wife who had died of illness only two years prior, and he was still not ready for a new relationship.
But Eloise, the only waitress working there, wasn't satisfied with this explanation.
She insisted on serving him, even when his plate or coffee cup was already in Julio's hands, snatching them away and briskly bringing them to his table, trying to brush against him every time.
as if by accident, giggling, purring, and continuing to hope.

Despite her beauty and vitality, nothing about her stirred him, not her large breasts as she leaned over him, not her prominent Dominican backside, and least of all the smell of cheap perfume wafting from her.
He did not want to insult her, and was careful to be courteous and polite.
Not too blunt so as not to provoke hostility from her, trying to remain in the shadow of himself.
to keep gazing mainly at the entrance to the right of the cafe, just across the street.
One evening, while climbing the stairs to his home, a feeling swept over him that someone else was in the stairwell.
He recognized a familiar cheap scent, momentarily unable to recall what it was, and cautiously, suspiciously, took the last steps to his apartment.
His hand reaching over his hip to feel the gun hidden inside his jacket.
He climbed the last set of stairs, raised his eyes, and saw her standing at his apartment door in provocative dress.
A dress shorter than usual, a neckline that left nothing to the imagination.
Her lips painted in red lipstick, and on her feet high heels, shaking her thick hair towards him.
He stopped in his tracks, realizing there was no way to escape, and tried to come up with something to say to get her to leave him alone.

As he approached her, ascending the last four steps, he began coughing persistently, laying his hand on his forehead, leaning on the stair railing, and said, I think I'm coming down with dengue and should get into bed.
Alone, he added, so there would be no doubt.
She gave him a look full of pity and reached out toward his forehead.
He caught her hand before she touched him, seemingly a bit too firmly, and said, Look, Eloise, I'm sorry.
You're a lovely girl, but I really am not interested.
Understand I am still mourning my wife and my heart is not open.
Besides, I truly don't feel well.
Let's leave it as it is.
Let's stay cafe friends.
The whole time he spoke, he held her wrist firmly, as if fearing she might reach out and touch him.
Only when he finished did he release her hand, noticing the red mark he left.
God Almighty, he really must be careful.
She looked at him again with sadness, but her eyes sparkled, and he hoped not with anger.
She muttered a juicy curse to herself, and in the same breath said, I'm sorry, Senior Pedro, I thought maybe you were shy and decided to take a chance.
It's not good to be alone all the time, but I understand.
I won't bother you again.
If you don't want, then it's not necessary.
Just know if you change your mind, you can always tell me to come."
For a moment, without being on guard, she leaned towards him, kissed his cheek and already tiptoed down the stairs, leaving behind that trail of cheap scent.
He quickly opened the door and locked it behind him, then leaned against it in full height and let out a sigh of relief.

He closed his eyes and immediately he saw the image of his girl from the pink house, almost smelling the fresh scent of her washed hair, seeing her standing at the garden gate, gazing with dreamy eyes towards the sea, into the distance.
Waiting for him to come, he missed her painfully.
How did his soul connect to hers so quickly?
How does he know she's the one?
A little more, he asked in his heart, a little more and I'll be back.
